thread.title: REVIEW: 9 to 5 Music Theatre South & The Stage Door
thread.title_full: REVIEW: 9 to 5 Music Theatre South & The Stage Door

title: REVIEW: 9 to 5 Music Theatre South & The Stage Door
text:
0 comments 
THIS popular musical, featuring Dolly Parton’s songs, had the opening-night audience enthralled. 
Co-directors Adam Myers and Sam Quested cast a trio of debutants in the leading roles, and they didn’t disappoint. 
The story follows the period after nervous Judy (Kimberly Wren) starts work at Consolidated Industries, run by lecherous president Franklin Hart Jnr (a great performance by Perry Rails). 
Judy forms an unlikely alliance with ultra-efficient Violet (Lyndsey Whettingsteel) and the sexually-harassed Doralee (Darcy Kearley) in plotting Hart’s downfall. 
All three, along with Sarah Mulcare’s performance (as Roz) were very impressive and treated us to several musical-highlights, including Shine like the sun and Change It. 
Violet’s duet with Joe (Myers) Let love grow and Judy’s solo Get out and stay out also drew well-deserved applause. 
James RH Sayers inventively choreographed the cast in the tight-confines of the stage with the always-impressive Stacey Barnett featuring. Share article 
Darren Alderton’s band was lively and the cast worked minor-miracles in continually re-setting the stage. Runs until October 31. 
Alan Johns REVIEW: 9 to 5 Music Theatre South & The Stage Door Sorry, an error occurred.
